Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This North Carolina State University project: Research Scholars Program in Mathematics is a continuation of their existing and effective four year S-STEM grant. The current project intends to provide scholarships to six undergraduates and eight graduate students in mathematics. The focus of the program will be on junior and senior undergraduates and graduate students in their first two years of study with special attention being paid to members of underrepresented groups. Particularly noteworthy is that all scholars, both undergraduate and graduate, will have the opportunity to be involved in either research or an internship. Additionally, scholars will attend weekly Professional Development Modules (where they will learn skills such as LaTex, Matlab, PowerPoint, etc.) and monthly seminars and will be mentored individually by a faculty member. The Research Scholars Program infrastructure can be adapted to other disciplines and will benefit not only students at NCSU, but can also impact the discipline of mathematics itself.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of our Research Scholars Program is to provide financial support to  undergraduate students in their junior or senior year and graduate students in their first two years of graduate study. We accomplish this by using a multi­faceted approach to provide a comprehensive educational environment for students in mathematics, especially traditionally underrepresented groups. The program integrates long established in­-place campus support programs and academic initiatives at North Carolina State University with new and innovative approaches to provide a comprehensive, challenging, yet supportive academic environment for students in mathematics. These include an enhanced curriculum to better prepare undergraduates for applied and interdisciplinary graduate programs and careers, research and internship experiences with dedicated faculty mentors/industrial partners to ensure excellent training of a new generation of mathematicians, professional development modules that will focus on research and career topics not typically covered in coursework, and opportunities for networking, support and mentorship to provide a welcoming and supportive community of researchers to students from underrepresented groups.

During this award, we provide need-based scholarships to 65 students (22 undergraduate and 43 graduate students). The undergraduate scholarship recipients are outstanding students with an average cumulative GPA of 3.78/4.0. In addition, they have received multiple honors, including a member of the NC State team that was designated a Meritorious Winner of the 2017 Interdisciplinary Contest in Modeling (ICM) (top 10% of 8085 participating teams). In addition, among the 11 NC State students who participated in the 2017 Virginia Tech Regional Mathematics Contest, the first place went to a S-STEM scholarship recipient. Finally, 15 NC State students participated in the 2018 William Lowell Putnam Competition, which is a preeminent mathematics competition for undergraduate students. Among the NC State participants, one of the S-STEM scholarship recipient was placed in the top three.

The award also made equal impact on the graduate program. It gives our first year graduate students times to devote to course work and participate in the program specific activities. In fact, most of our graduate S-STEM scholarship recipients were signing up to take 2 or all 3 one-year sequences of course work for the written qualifying examination. For comparison, our graduate students, normally, would sign up to take 1 sequence after one year and 2 sequences the next year. As they took care of the written qualifying examination early in their graduate study, the S-STEM recipients could select their Ph.D. advisors early, and, this would lead to a shorter time to degree for these students. 

Finally, the award also made impact to the physical resources at NC State University. A new web lab experiment studying the population dynamics of Daphnia and a new chemostat experiment for the growth of micro-organisms were developed. These experiments were integrated into the modeling as well as differential equations for the life sciences courses developed as a component of the enhanced curriculum component of the S-STEM program and will allow us to train future generations of mathematicians in data collection and mathematical model development.
